TEXT: The applicants , PERSON and PERSON , are NORP nationals , born in DATE and DATE respectively and living in GPE . They are represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by Mr PERSON , Director in ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicants and CARDINAL other animal rights activists attempted to colour the fur of foxes kept at a farm in GPE , when its owner fired at them with a shot gun , injuring CARDINAL of them , including the first applicant . They were apprehended by the police on DATE at TIME on their way to hospital . CARDINAL of them was later admitted for hospital care .

On DATE at TIME Senior Police Officer PERSON of ORG in PERSON telephoned judge PERSON at FAC ( käräjäoikeus , tingsrätt ) to convey a detention request concerning “ CARDINAL suspects ” , including the applicants .

The respective written requests received at ORG in TIME the same day stated the ORG name , address and identity number and indicated that they were under suspicion for having committed the following offences : CARDINAL count of aggravated violation of domestic peace in GPE on DATE at TIME ; CARDINAL counts of aggravated damage to property in the region of GPE ( GPE ) on DATE ; and CARDINAL counts of damage to property in GPE on DATE . The requests were accompanied by a memorandum by GPE setting out the facts in more detail .

The second applicant ’s continued detention was considered by ORG on DATE from TIME and the first applicant ’s detention was examined from TIME They received copies of the detention request immediately prior to the respective hearings .

Before ORG , defence counsel argued that the detention request concerning the second applicant was inadmissible as it had not been submitted in proper and lawful form before TIME . According to TIME from the hearing , GPE contested counsel ’s argument as he had informed the court before TIME that the request concerned CARDINAL arrested persons held in GPE and connected to the events at the fox farm in GPE . In addition , GPE had informed the court that their detention was being sought in respect of the acts committed in GPE and GPE as well .
In dismissing counsel ’s objection ORG found as follows :

“ Since the head of the investigation [ GPE ] informed the court orally , on DATE before TIME as prescribed by law , that he was going to request ( ilmoittanut tulevansa vaatimaan ) the detention of CARDINAL persons in respect of CARDINAL count of aggravated violation of domestic peace committed in GPE , CARDINAL counts of aggravated damage to property and CARDINAL counts of damage to property , and even though he did not at that stage indicate the names of those whose detention was being sought , [ his ] request was nevertheless confirmed in writing without delay . As there was no risk of any error occurring in respect of the persons and the offences in question , [ the court ] finds that the detention request was made in accordance with the law . ”

ORG went on to dismiss the detention request in respect of all but the first applicant , who was ordered to remain in detention until DATE on suspicion of having committed the CARDINAL counts of aggravated damage to property and the CARDINAL counts of damage to property , as indicated in the request .

ORG further ordered that the case - file , with the exception of the detention order and the legal provisions applied , be kept secret until the first hearing of the charges against the suspects or until the pre - trial investigation against them had been closed . ORG applied section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL , of LAW ( laki oikeudenkäynnin julkisuudesta , lag om offentlighet vid rättegång CARDINAL ) .

On DATE the first applicant filed a procedural appeal ( kantelu ) with ORG ( hovioikeus , hovrätt ) , contending that the detention request had not been made in accordance with the law as it had not been filed in writing without delay . The written request had been faxed to her counsel ’s office only at TIME and counsel himself had received it TIME In any case , the offences specified in support of the request did not correspond to those which GPE had apparently communicated to judge NORP over the telephone .

In a written statement to ORG judge PERSON explained that in his telephone call to ORG which GPE had placed on DATE before TIME he had first informed a court secretary that he was seeking the detention of CARDINAL arrested persons connected with the events that had occurred at a fox farm in GPE . Immediately thereafter GPE had informed judge NORP that their detention was also being requested for the acts committed in GPE and GPE . Although GPE had not at that time specified the names of the CARDINAL suspects in question , judge NORP found that there was no uncertainty as to their identities and the offences of which they were suspected . She had therefore concluded that the detention request had been submitted in accordance with law .

In its decision of DATE ORG agreed with ORG , finding that at the time when the detention request had been presented over the telephone there had been no uncertainty as to the fact that the request concerned , among others , the second applicant or as to the offences of which she was being suspected .

ORG maintained ORG secrecy order and further ordered that its own decision , again with the exception of the operative part and the legal provisions applied , also be kept secret until the first hearing of the charges against the suspects or until the pre - trial investigation against them had been closed .

ORG ( korkein oikeus , högsta domstolen ) refused the first applicant leave to appeal on DATE . The decision bore a stamp indicating that it was “ secret ” . It contained the standard reasoning which ORG relies on when refusing leave to appeal , without referring to the applicable legal provision ( see “ Relevant domestic law ” ) :
“ Leave to appeal is refused . ORG decision therefore stands . ”

In the meantime , the first applicant ’s detention had been prolonged . On DATE ORG had ordered her release , having accepted her further procedural appeal of DATE . This appellate court , noting the progress in the pre - trial investigation , found that her continued detention was no longer necessary in order to secure an effective investigation and trial .

According to LAW ( pakkokeinolaki , tvångsmedelslag TIME , as amended by Acts nos . ORG and CARDINAL ) , an arrested person and his or her legal counsel shall be notified without delay of a request for detention on remand ( section CARDINAL ) . Such a request shall be made to the court without delay and not TIME on DATE from DATE of the apprehension of the suspect ( section CARDINAL ) . The request shall be made in writing . It may also be submitted orally or by telephone but shall then be confirmed in writing without delay ( section CARDINAL ) .

According to an expert opinion relied on by the applicants , an oral or telephone request must identify the person , the offence of which he or she is being suspected as well as the ground for the detention ( PERSON , PERSON and PERSON : Uusi esitutkintalainsäädäntö . GPE DATE ) .
A request for detention on remand shall be considered by the court without delay and not DATE from the moment the suspect was placed in custody ( section CARDINAL ) .

An arrested person shall be released immediately when the conditions for his or her arrest no longer exist . If his or her detention on remand is not requested , the release shall take place no later than at the expiry of the aforementioned period for submitting such a request ( section CARDINAL ) .

LAW , section CARDINAL of LAW stipulates that a procedural appeal against detention on remand may be submitted at any time and shall be dealt with expeditiously . In its precedent no . CARDINAL ORG ( by CARDINAL votes DATE ) held that it was not prevented from introducing a leave requirement for such appeals .

Under LAW ( laki yleisten asiakirjain julkisuudesta , lag om allmänna handlingars offentlighet CARDINAL , as in force until repealed by Act no . CARDINAL ) , official documents were in principle public ( section CARDINAL ) . They included not only documents drawn up and issued by an authority but also documents submitted to an authority and which remained in its possession ( section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ) . A pre - trial investigation record , however , was not public until the matter had been brought before a court or the police investigation had been closed without charges being brought ( section CARDINAL ) .

The DATE LAW ( laki oikeudenkäynnin julkisuudesta , lag om offentlighet vid rättegång ORG , as amended by Act no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) affords the court the option of holding a hearing in camera , inter alia when examining a request for detention on remand to be dealt with prior to the actual trial , provided such a request has been made by the head of the pre - trial investigation or the suspect himself or if the court deems it necessary to exclude the public from the hearing ( LAW ) . If the suspects requests a detention hearing in camera , the public shall be allowed to attend only for a particularly weighty reason .

If a detention hearing has been held in camera in whole or in part or if , during such a hearing , any confidential document or information has been submitted , the court may decide that all or part of the case material shall be kept confidential until the beginning of the trial or the discontinuation of the investigation . The operative part of the reasoning and the legal provisions relied on shall always be made public ( section CARDINAL , as amended by Act no . DATE ) .

Under LAW , sections CARDINAL of the Code of Judicial Procedure ( PERSON , PERSON Balk ) ORG may only on certain circumscribed grounds grant leave to appeal against a decision or judgment rendered by a court of appeal in appeal proceedings .
